user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Hook_GetArgPtr:
```c
const void *UT_Hook_GetArgPtr(const UT_StubContext_t *ContextPtr, const char *Name, size_t ExpectedTypeSize)
{
    uint32                      i;
    const void *                Result;
    const UT_StubArgMetaData_t *MetaPtr;

    static const union
    {
        unsigned long AsInt;
        void *        AsPtr;
        double        AsFloat;
    } ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE = {0};

    Result = NULL;
    for (i = 0; i < ContextPtr->ArgCount; ++i)
    {
        MetaPtr = &ContextPtr->Meta[i];
        if (MetaPtr->Name != NULL)
        {
            if (strcmp(MetaPtr->Name, Name) == 0 && (MetaPtr->Size == 0 || MetaPtr->Size == ExpectedTypeSize))
            {
                if (MetaPtr->Type == UT_STUBCONTEXT_ARG_TYPE_DIRECT)
                {
                    Result = &ContextPtr->ArgPtr[i];
                }
                else if (MetaPtr->Type == UT_STUBCONTEXT_ARG_TYPE_INDIRECT)
                {
                    Result = ContextPtr->ArgPtr[i];
                }
                break;
            }
        }
    }

    /*
     * If no suitable result pointer was found, this means a mismatch
     * between the stub and test case, such as a change in argument/parameter names.
     * This is an error that should be corrected, so report it as a failure.
     */
    if (Result == NULL)
    {
        UtAssert_Failed("Requested parameter %s of size %lu which was not provided by the stub", Name,
                        (unsigned long)ExpectedTypeSize);

        if (ExpectedTypeSize <= sizeof(ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE))
        {
            Result = &ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE;
        }
        else
        {
            /*
             * As the caller will likely dereference the returned pointer, should
             * never return NULL.  Just abort here.
             */
            UtAssert_Abort("No value for parameter");
        }
    }

    return Result;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_Hook_GetArgPtr:
typedef struct
{
    int32                Int32StatusCode;
    bool                 Int32StatusIsSet;
    uint32               ArgCount;
    const void *         ArgPtr[UT_STUBCONTEXT_MAXSIZE];
    UT_StubArgMetaData_t Meta[UT_STUBCONTEXT_MAXSIZE];
} UT_StubContext_t
...
typedef struct
{
    UT_StubContext_Arg_Type_t Type;
    const char *              Name;
    size_t                    Size;
} UT_StubArgMetaData_t
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
#define UtAssert_Failed(__VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(false,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
void UtAssert_Abort(const char *Message)
{
    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT, Message);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not find any use of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. The following constructs were inspected and are standard C (not compiler extensions):

- The static const union ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE with initializer = {0} is a standard anonymous (unnamed) union type definition with a variable initialization — this is allowed by standard C.
- Implicit conversion between object pointers and void * (e.g., assigning &ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE to a const void *) is standard C pointer behavior.
- Use of size_t and casting to unsigned long for printf-style formatting is standard C (not an extension); the code uses an explicit cast to match %lu.
- The for-loop and increment ++i are standard C.
- The strcmp, NULL pointer tests, pointer dereferences, and structure members usage are standard.
- The UtAssert_Failed macro uses the standard C99 variadic macro __VA_ARGS__ form; variadic macros are part of the C99 standard (not a compiler extension when compiling in a C99-or-later mode).
- Use of fixed-width integer typedefs (uint32_t) and typedef alias uint32 is standard (stdint.h is part of C99).

No occurrences were found of known compiler extensions such as GCC/Clang attributes (__attribute__), typeof, __extension__, inline assembly (asm), builtins (__builtin_*), Microsoft-specific extensions (like __declspec), or other vendor-specific language constructs. Therefore there are no code fragments that need to be flagged for investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions).
